'''Tram Nybol'''<ref group="note">The name ''Tram Nybol'' only appears in ''[[Parma Eldalamberon]]'', a linguistic journal.</ref> was a grey, arched bridge crossing the rivers [[Afros]] and [[Gruir]] at their confluence near the [[House of the Hundred Chimneys]] in [[Tavrobel]], according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref name="Nyb">{{PE|13}}, "[[Heraldic Devices of Tol Erethrin]]", p. 94</ref><ref>{{LT1|VIII}}, p. 175</ref>

[[File:J.R.R. Tolkien - Taurobel.png|thumb|left|100px|''Taurobel'' by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]], depicting the bridge of Tavrobel]]
After the disastrous [[Battle of the Heath of the Sky-roof]] during the [[Faring Forth]], the [[Elves]] and, according to one outline, [[Eriol]], crossed Afros and Gruir in an attempt to escape the invading [[Men]], presumably at Tram Nybol.<ref>{{LT2|VI}}, outline '''8''', p. 287</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Tram Nybol'' is in [[Gnomish]]. The first element of the name is ''[[tram]]'' ("bridge"), but the second element ''Nybol'' is unclear, possibly being an adjectival form of ''[[nib]]'' ("snowflake") - therefore, the name might mean "Snowy Bridge", although it is not obvious why such a name might be appropriate.<ref name="Nyb"/>

== Inspiration ==
Tram Nybol might have been inspired by the [[wikipedia:Essex Bridge, Staffordshire|Essex Bridge]], crossing the river [[wikipedia:River Trent|Trent]] near the village of [[wikipedia:Great Haywood|Great Haywood]] (which was the inspiration for Tavrobel).<ref name="Nyb"/>
